attributes.action: REINTRODUCE RELIEF OF THE 20% CORPORATION TAX ON PENSION FUNDS
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
The relief for Pension Funds of the 20% tax on Corporate Profits was removed by the Chancellor in 1997, on the grounds that, 'Pension Funds were awash with cash'
This may have been true at that time, and it removed an estimated £5 billion per annum from Pension Funds.
UK Pension Funds are no longer awash with cash, but rather with the anguish of Members who feel robbed, after years of sacrifices to ensure a comfortable Retirement.
Since that time, financial pressures have built up which have severely damaged the viability of UK Pension Funds, especially the Defined Benefit schemes. (linked to Final Salaries) 
 Cannot the same people who defended the original removal of the Tax relief, ask themselves the same question now; if they concede that Pension Funds are no longer cash-rich, then reintroduce the Tax Relief
(Or risk having to pay an equivalent sum each year to Pensioners in poverty, via some degrading 'Means-tested' scheme)

rejection.details: Please resubmit without using BLOCK CAPS as they are more difficult for people to read.
reasons: Wording that needs to be amended, or is impossible to understand
